title-group.article-title: Two new species of Dasybasis Macquart from the Peruvian Andes of Cusco (Diptera: Tabanidae: Diachlorini)

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
1
Instituto de Entomología, Facultad de Ciencias Básicas, Universidad Metropolitana de Ciencias de la Educación, Santiago , Chile .

2
Laboratorio de Entomología, Universidad Nacional de San Antonio Abad del Cusco , Cusco , Perú .

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Two new horse fly species,
Dasybasis mancoi
sp. nov. and
D. huaynai
sp. nov. ( Diptera : Tabanidae : Diachlorini ), are described from the Peruvian Andes near Cusco on the basis of morphological features, including those of the female genitalia. Digital photographs of both species and of the terminalia of both females and of one male are provided. The two new species are related to
D. bulbula Coscarón & Philip
, as evidenced by their similar morphological characteristics.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words: Horse fly , morphology , Neotropical Region , new species ,
Peru

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Tabanid flies are found in a wide range of habitats, including forests, grasslands, wetlands, and water bodies. They are distributed globally, with species found on every continent except Antarctica . Adult female tabanids are known for their painful and irritating bites, as many species feed on the blood of mammals, including humans, livestock, and wildlife. Most female tabanids require blood meals to develop and lay their eggs, whereas males typically feed on nectar. Besides being painful, tabanid bites in some cases can transmit diseases (
).

Studies on Peruvian Tabanidae include those of
,
,
;
;
),
,
,
,
,
, and
. However, the taxonomy of the tribe Diachlorini is still not completely resolved, and many groups still await study.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
Morphological terminology used herein follows that of
. The specimens were examined under a Nikon SMZ 1500 trinocular stereomicroscope. The “frontal index” is the ratio between the longitudinal length and the basal width of the frons. Terminalia were macerated in a 10% KOH solution at 50º C for one hour to dissolve the soft tissue. They were then neutralized with acetic acid, rinsed in distilled water, and dissected in 80% ethanol. Digital photographs were taken by use of a Nikon DS-Fi2 camera mounted on a Nikon SMZ 1500 trinocular stereomicroscope. Depth of the field was enhanced by use of Nikon ACT-2U software to stack multiple images.

Acronyms of depository institutions: UMCE (Instituto de Entomología, Universidad Metropolitana de Ciencias de la Educación, Santiago , Chile ), UNSAAC (Universidad Nacional de San Antonio Abad del Cusco , Perú ).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Dasybasis mancoi
and
D. huaynai
exhibit generalized features characteristic of the genus
Dasybasis
: general color of the body grayish; eyes sparsely covered by ommatrichia and without bands; frons wide, rarely convergent at the base; basal callus quadrangular, touching eyes; ocellar triangle vestigial; ocelli vestigial; subcallus bare; antennae with pruinosity and without dorsal projection on basal flagellomere, scape variable in shape, pedicel generally with dorsal projection; maxillary palpi stout and short; scutum with longitudinal stripes reaching notopleural lobe; wings hyaline or with clouds on the veins, with short setae on Sc and R 1 with several rows of setae; abdomen with longitudinal stripes and with triangles on tergites (
;
).

Dasybasis mancoi
is similar to
D. bulbula Coscarón & Philip
in general appearance (frons slightly convergent, basal callus touching eyes, scape globose, and mesonotum color), but
D. mancoi
differs in the following external characters: frontal index, eyes with very abundant ommatrichia, shape and color of frontal callus, subcallus bare, pedicel without dorsal projection, wings slightly smoky, without appendix on R 4 , basicosta bare, shape of gonapophysis, and genital fork with base convex ( Table 1 ).
Dasybasis huaynai
is also close to
D. bulbula
, but the latter differs in size, frons slightly convergent, basal callus shape, wing slightly smoky, and palpus with black and gray setulae ( Table 1 ). In addition to the characteristics mentioned, other differences among some species of
Dasybasis
are shown in Table 1 .

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: We thank William L. Murphy, Research Collaborator with the Department of Entomology, National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington , DC, USA , for reviewing the manuscript and for help in editing the English version.
